misconceptions.name: While loop never updates the guess (infinite loop)
misconceptions.description: The program reads the user's guess once before the while loop and never reads a new guess inside the loop body. As a result, the loop condition is checked against the same value every time, so the game either terminates immediately (if the first guess is correct) or becomes an infinite loop that prints hints without ever asking for another guess.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that putting the input statement before the while loop is enough for the loop to "keep asking" the user until they guess correctly.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A while loop only repeats its body; it does not automatically obtain new input. For a guessing game, you must read a new guess (e.g., with nextInt()) inside the loop so that the loop condition can eventually become false when the user guesses correctly.
symptoms: If the initial guess is not 7, the program loops forever printing "Too low, try again!" or "Too high, try again!" without asking for another guess.
The variable user_guess is never changed inside the loop, so the condition user_guess != correct_answer never becomes false unless it was false initially.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how while loops interact with changing state: the student did not realize that the loop body must modify the variables used in the condition (by reading new input) to allow the loop to terminate.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Move the input reading for the guess inside the while loop. For example, at the end of the loop body, prompt the user again and assign user_guess = input_scanner.nextInt(); so the condition is checked against an updated value each iteration.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly reads user_guess once before the loop and never updates it inside the loop, a classic infinite-loop pattern in guessing games.

evidence.note: user_guess is read once before the loop and never updated inside the loop, so the while condition is always checked against the same value.

misconceptions.name: Using a hard-coded answer instead of a random number in the required range
misconceptions.description: The program uses a fixed integer correct_answer = 7 and asks the user to guess a number between 1 and 10, instead of generating a random number between 1 and 100 as specified. It also does not use the Random class at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that a guessing game can be implemented by choosing a constant secret number (such as 7) and does not need to use a random number generator or the required 1–100 range.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this task, the secret number must be generated randomly in the range 1 to 100 using Random, for example: Random rand = new Random(); int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1; The prompt should also match this 1–100 range.
symptoms: The secret number is always 7 on every run.
The prompt asks for a number between 1 and 10 instead of 1 and 100.
The Random class is never used, so the game does not meet the randomness requirement.
misconceptions.root_cause: The student either ignored or misunderstood the requirement to use a random number between 1 and 100, and instead treated the guessing game as practice with a fixed sentinel value.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hard-coded correct_answer with a randomly generated value using the Random class, and update the prompt to match the 1–100 range. For example: Random rand = new Random(); int correct_answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1; System.out.print("Guess the secret number between 1 and 100: ");
related_concepts: Matching user prompts to program requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code clearly sets correct_answer = 7, uses a 1–10 prompt, and never uses Random, directly contradicting the problem specification.

evidence.note: correct_answer is hard-coded to 7 and the prompt uses a 1–10 range; no Random-based 1–100 number is generated.

misconceptions.name: Infinite loop due to lack of variable update
misconceptions.description: The student placed the user input statement (the read operation) outside the `while` loop. Consequently, the variable used in the loop condition (`user_guess`) is never updated after the loop starts, causing the program to become stuck in an infinite loop if the initial guess is incorrect.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that once the `while` loop starts, the variables used in the condition are somehow automatically updated, or they forgot that the input operation (`input_scanner.nextInt()`) must be repeated inside the loop body to progress toward the termination condition.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A `while` loop must ensure that one or more variables involved in its condition are modified inside the loop body. When looping based on user input, the input must be read repeatedly within the loop.
symptoms: Program outputs the same hint repeatedly without pausing or prompting for new input
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how variables and control flow work within iteration constructs, particularly concerning updating state based on external input.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Move the code that prompts and reads the user's guess into the body of the `while` loop so that `user_guess` is updated on every iteration.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: This is a clear, standard error where input necessary for loop termination is omitted from the loop body.

evidence.note: The input is read here, before the loop starts. It is never read again inside the loop body (lines 48-59).

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded Answer instead of Random Generation
misconceptions.description: The student hardcoded the secret number (7) and used a range of 1-10, failing to implement the required use of the `Random` class to select a number between 1 and 100.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student may have focused solely on the loop logic and intentionally ignored the setup instructions, or they believe a hardcoded number fulfills the spirit of the assignment for testing purposes (despite the strict problem instruction).
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem requires using `java.util.Random` to ensure the secret number changes on each run, specifically within the 1-100 range.
symptoms: The game answer is always 7.
misconceptions.root_cause: Failure to follow the specific setup instructions provided in the problem statement/hint, prioritizing loop practice over game state initialization.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Review the hint provided in the problem statement and replace the hardcoded answer with the random number generation logic.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly hardcodes the value and range requirement is violated.

evidence.snippet:
// declare the correct answer for the guessing game
        int correct_answer = 7;
evidence.note: The answer is hardcoded as 7 instead of being generated randomly between 1 and 100.

misconceptions.name: Missing input re-read inside loop
misconceptions.description: Student reads user input only once before the loop, then never reads it again inside the loop. This causes the loop condition to check the same unchanged variable repeatedly, creating an infinite loop.
misconceptions.student_belief: The while loop will automatically re-evaluate with new input, or the input variable will somehow be refreshed without explicitly calling nextInt() again.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Variables hold their assigned value until explicitly reassigned. You must call input_scanner.nextInt() inside the loop body to read a new guess each iteration. The while condition only checks the current value of the variable.
symptoms: Program enters infinite loop after first guess
Same feedback message repeats indefinitely
Program never reaches the 'You got it!' message
misconceptions.root_cause: Student does not understand that reading input is an explicit operation that must be called each time a new value is needed. They may believe the loop structure itself refreshes input automatically.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add 'user_guess = input_scanner.nextInt();' as the first line inside the while loop body, before the if statements. This will read a new guess from the user on each iteration.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Code clearly shows nextInt() called only once at line 55, never inside the while loop (lines 57-67). This is a straightforward structural error that directly causes infinite loop behavior.

evidence.note: Input is read at line 55 before the loop, but never again inside the loop body (lines 59-65). The loop condition at line 57 will always check the same unchanging user_guess value, causing infinite loop.

misconceptions.name: Hardcoded answer instead of random generation
misconceptions.description: Student hardcoded the answer to 7 instead of using the Random class to generate a random number between 1 and 100 as explicitly required by the problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: Using a fixed test value is acceptable for this problem, or the student forgot to implement the Random functionality.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem explicitly requires generating a random number between 1 and 100 using 'Random rand = new Random(); int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1;' as provided in the hint. The game should have a different answer each time it runs.
symptoms: Answer is always 7, not random
Game range is 1-10, not 1-100 as specified
No Random import or Random object created
misconceptions.root_cause: Either careless omission of the Random setup code or misunderstanding that the problem requires randomness as a core feature.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add 'import java.util.Random;' at the top. Then replace 'int correct_answer = 7;' with 'Random rand = new Random(); int correct_answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1;'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Problem statement and hint explicitly require random 1-100. Student's code uses hardcoded 7 with no Random import or Random object. Clear violation of stated requirement.

evidence.snippet:
// declare the correct answer for the guessing game
int correct_answer = 7;
evidence.note: Hardcoded answer of 7 instead of using Random class. No Random import present. Problem explicitly requires random number 1-100.

misconceptions.name: Missing guess counter and result display
misconceptions.description: Student does not implement a counter to track the number of guesses, and does not display the required output format showing how many guesses it took. The output message does not match the specification.
misconceptions.student_belief: Displaying the guess count is optional or not required.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem sample output explicitly shows 'Correct! You took 3 guesses.' A guess counter variable must be initialized, incremented in the loop, and displayed in the final message.
symptoms: No counter variable declared or initialized
Loop body does not increment a counter
Output message is 'You got it!' instead of 'Correct! You took X guesses.'
Guess count is never calculated or displayed
misconceptions.root_cause: Student did not fully implement the required functionality. They implemented the core game logic but omitted the counter tracking feature shown in the specification.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add 'int guess_count = 0;' before the loop. Then add 'guess_count++;' inside the loop body. Finally, change the output message to 'System.out.println("Correct! You took " + guess_count + " guesses.");'
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Sample output in problem explicitly shows guess count. Student's code has no counter variable, no increment in loop, and output message does not match specification. Clear omission of required feature.

evidence.snippet:
// if the loop finishes, then the user must have guessed correctly
System.out.println("You got it!");
evidence.note: Output message does not include guess count. Should display 'Correct! You took X guesses.' as shown in problem sample output.

misconceptions.name: Guess value is never updated inside the loop (infinite loop risk)
misconceptions.description: The program reads the user's guess once before the while-loop and never reads a new guess inside the loop body. As a result, the same guess is checked over and over, so the loop will never terminate unless the initial guess happens to equal the secret number.
misconceptions.student_belief: Reading the user's guess once before entering the loop is enough; the while-loop will somehow allow the user to try again without explicitly calling nextInt() inside the loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For a guessing game, the program must read a new guess on each iteration of the loop. That means calling input_scanner.nextInt() inside the loop body (or at the end of a do-while loop) so that user_guess is updated before the loop condition is checked again.
symptoms: If the first guess is not 7, the loop prints "Too low, try again!" or "Too high, try again!" forever and never gives the user a chance to enter a new guess.
The while-loop body only prints hints and then immediately rechecks the same user_guess value.
The success message "You got it!" is effectively unreachable for any initial guess other than 7.
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding how while-loops interact with input: treating the loop as if it automatically re-prompts for input each iteration instead of requiring an explicit read inside the loop.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Move the input_scanner.nextInt() call into the loop so user_guess is updated each time, e.g., prompt and read inside the while-loop, or use a do-while loop that always reads a new guess at the end of each iteration.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because user_guess is only assigned once before the loop and never changed inside the loop body, matching a classic infinite-loop pattern.

evidence.note: user_guess is read once before the loop and never updated inside the while-loop, so the same value is checked repeatedly.

misconceptions.name: Using a fixed constant instead of a random secret number in the required range
misconceptions.description: The program hardcodes the secret answer as 7 and uses a 1–10 range, instead of generating a random number between 1 and 100 as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: It is acceptable to choose a fixed secret number (7) and a 1–10 range for the guessing game, rather than generating a random number in the specified 1–100 range.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The secret number should be randomly chosen each time the program runs using Random (e.g., Random rand = new Random(); int answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1;), and the user should be guessing in the range 1–100 to match the problem statement.
symptoms: correct_answer is always 7 on every run of the program.
The user is prompted to "Guess the secret number between 1 and 10" instead of 1–100.
No Random object or nextInt(100) + 1 call appears anywhere in the code.
misconceptions.root_cause: Confusion or disregard of the problem requirements for randomness and range, possibly from reusing an earlier fixed-number guessing example without adapting it.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the hardcoded int correct_answer = 7; with a Random-based initialization: Random rand = new Random(); int correct_answer = rand.nextInt(100) + 1; and update the prompt to use the 1–100 range.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: High confidence because the code clearly declares a fixed constant 7 for the answer, uses a 1–10 prompt, and never references Random, directly contradicting the stated requirements.

evidence.note: The secret number is hardcoded as 7 and the prompt specifies 1–10 instead of generating a random number in the 1–100 range.
The program imports only Scanner and never uses Random or nextInt(100) + 1 as suggested in the problem statement.

misconceptions.name: Missing loop body update (Infinite Loop Potential)
misconceptions.description: The student correctly uses a while loop to check for the termination condition (`user_guess != correct_answer`) but fails to include code inside the loop body to re-read or update the `user_guess` variable. This causes the loop to run indefinitely once entered, regardless of the user's input.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that reading the input variable once before the loop is sufficient, or they forgot that the input-reading step must be repeated inside the loop to get a new guess from the user. They might think the `while` loop conditionally executes the body and somehow expects the variable to change without explicit input reading.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For a guessing game or iterative process that requires new inputs, the input-reading step must be placed inside the loop body so that the variable used in the loop condition is updated before the next iteration is evaluated.
symptoms: Program hangs after the first incorrect guess
The hints (Too low/Too high) are printed repeatedly without new input prompts
misconceptions.root_cause: Procedural failure to handle recurring input needs within an iteration construct.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Inside your `while` loop, after providing the hint, make sure to prompt the user again for a new guess and assign the result to the `user_guess` variable.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The missing input update inside the critical path of a loop designed for repeated input is a classic pattern resulting in an infinite loop.

evidence.note: The input reading is only done prior to the loop. The loop relies on `user_guess` which is never updated inside the loop body.

misconceptions.correct_understanding: The problem explicitly requires the computer to pick a random number between 1 and 100 using Java's `Random` class (`rand.nextInt(100) + 1`). Hardcoding a value defeats the essential purpose of the game being different each time.

misconceptions.name: Loop variable not updated inside loop
misconceptions.description: Student created a while loop that checks a condition but never updates the variable being checked inside the loop body. This causes an infinite loop when the initial guess is incorrect.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that once a while loop is entered, checking the same variable repeatedly will eventually satisfy the exit condition, or that they intend to keep showing feedback for the same guess indefinitely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: A while loop repeats its body, but variable values don't change unless explicitly modified inside the loop. To accept a new guess each iteration, must call input_scanner.nextInt() inside the loop body to overwrite the user_guess variable.
symptoms: Program hangs indefinitely if the first guess is incorrect
Same feedback message repeats forever
User cannot enter a new guess
misconceptions.root_cause: Misunderstanding of how variables persist their values across loop iterations; forgetting that external input (nextInt()) must be called again to refresh the variable
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add 'user_guess = input_scanner.nextInt();' as the last statement inside the while loop body, before the closing brace.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The student's own comment explicitly states 'the loop now goes back to the top and checks the same guess again', demonstrating they are aware of the behavior. The code clearly lacks any input reading statement inside the loop.

evidence.note: Input 'user_guess' is read only once before the loop. Inside the while loop body, there is no new input statement. The variable never changes, causing infinite loop if initial guess is wrong.
